position.marginalia_text: Quamcu[m]q[ue] latitudine[m] Planeta vel fixa lic[et] eius quadratus aspectus cadet in ecliptica[e] gradum nonagesimu[m] ab eius loco secundum longitudine[m]. et causa huius est quod ille punctus in ecliptica est instar poli istius circuti p[er] que[m] descripta est stell[a]e lo[n]gitudo, et co[n]tra q[u]ocumq[ue] puncto extra ecliptica[m] accept[o] si p[er] illud descributur circutus mag[nus] (vt su[n]t circuti lo[n]gitudinum) polus eius in ecliptica erit distans 90 gradus ab o[mn]i parte eius circuti, ad angulos rectos

marginalia.translation: Whichever latitude, the planet or fixed, although its rectangular appearance will fall into the ninteenth degree of the eclipse from its place according to the longitude. And it's cause is that this point in the eclipse is the image of that orbital pole through which the longitude of a star is described, and against, by whichever point [received] beyond the eclipse, if through that its great orbital pole is described (as are the orbits of longitudes) in the eclipse, shall be standing apart 90 degress from every part of its orbit, towards right angles
